frameDefinitions: An Agent manipulates a Fastener to open or close a Containing_object (e.g. coat, jar).
A Useful_location is accessible to some (possibly generic)
This frame contains adjectives and nouns that describe the truth or sincerity of communication.
An Obstruction blocks an Eclipsed entity partially or completely from view.
An Experiencer, Expressor, or State has a feeling of annoyance as evoked by a Stimulus or concerning a Topic.
A Phenomenon, which may be an activity, state or object, is purposefully hidden from the awareness of a potential Cognizer.
frameExamples: Mary <t>closed</t> her coat with a belt.
I left the door to the lobby <t>open</t> for you.
Evelyn was <t>candid</t> with me about the party.
A small green bulb <t>concealed</t> behind the panel flashed on momentarily .
Few people would use ATMs if the content of their transaction was <t>secret</t> from their bank and there was no paper trail verifying the transaction. .
listRoleDefinitions:
This role identifies the item that is closed by the agent with the fastener.
<fex name='Agent'>Lee</fex> <t>buttoned</t> <fex name='Containing_object'>his coat</fex>.
The Agent opens/closes the Containing-object.
This role identifies the fastener that the agent manipulates.
This role identifies the active zone of the container that may be expressed as the direct object of the target verb.
The time at which the <fen>Agent</fen> closes the <fen>Container_portal</fen> or the <fen>Containing_object</fen>.
The location where the closing event takes place.
The <fen>Theme</fen> whose motion is blocked or free.
The place or thing that the <fen>Theme</fen> is headed towards, despite a potential or actual <fen>Barrier</fen>.
An entity that (at least potentially) prevents the <fen>Theme</fen> from getting to the <fen>Useful_location</fen>.
The time when the <fen>Useful_location</fen> is or is not accessible.

The <fen>Speaker</fen> produces the <fen>Message</fen>, the truth or sincerity of which is at issue. It is normally expressed as the External Argument of predicative uses of the <t>target</t> word, or as the Nominal Head of prenominal uses.

<fen>Message</fen> is the communicative content whose truth or sincerity is at issue. This role does not normally co-occur with the other FEs in this frame. When it does occur, it is normally the External Argument of a predicative use of the <t>Target</t> word, or the modified Nominal Head in a prenominal use.

The <fen>Topic</fen> is the subject matter to which the <fen>Message</fen> pertains. It often occurs without the <fen>Message</fen> role in predicative uses of the <t>target</t> word. It is normally expressed as a PP Complement headed by 'about'.
<fen>Medium</fen> is the physical or abstract setting in which the <fen>Message</fen> is conveyed.
The entity which blocks the <fen>Eclipsed</fen> entity from view.
The entity which is blocked from view.
The <fen>Experiencer</fen> is the person or sentient entity that experiences or feels the emotions.
The <fen>Topic</fen> is the general area in which the emotion occurs.  It indicates a range of possible <fen>Stimulus</fen>.
The <fen>Stimulus</fen> is the person, event, or state of affairs that evokes the emotional response in the <fen>Experiencer</fen>.

The body part, gesture, or other expression of the <fen>Experiencer</fen> that reflects his or her emotional state.  They describe a presentation of the experience or emotion denoted by the adjective or noun.
The <fen>State</fen> is the abstract noun that describes a more lasting experience by the <fen>Experiencer</fen>.
The <fen>Time</fen> when the <fen>Experiencer</fen>, <fen>Expressor</fen>, or <fen>State</fen> can be described as having said emotion.
The <fen>Phenomenon</fen> is the activity, state or object that is purposefully hidden from the awareness of a potential cognizer.
A period of <fen>Time</fen> during which the <fen>Phenomenon</fen> is hidden from the awareness of potential cognizers.
listRoleExamples: Marcus tied his shoe <fex>with the neon-green shoelaces</fex>.
They close the bank vault <fex>at precisely 5:35PM</fex>.
Shouldn't you have buttoned that <fex>in the bathroom</fex>?
Evelyn made some candid remarks <fex>in French</fex>.
The mists obscured <fex>the top of the tower</fex>.
There was stuff in there that was 'secret' <fex>in the 1980s</fex>, but has since become pretty common knowledge.

sourceCandidateSpans.text: The Great Financial Crisis of 1914 and the Origins of America's Monetary Supremacy
When Washington Shut Down Wall Street
the beginning of the century to 1914
The New York Stock Exchange in the Crisis of 1914
